top_categories.workout_context: Rad am Ring Gravel's German Eifel, European gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 62 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Rad am Ring Gravel's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before July.
65ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Rad am Ring Gravel, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rad am Ring Gravel. Train it until it feels boring.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Rad am Ring Gravel, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
62 miles on german Eifel gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Varied gradients on german Eifel gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
When someone attacks on german Eifel gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on german Eifel gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Smooth pedaling at 62 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Rad am Ring Gravel’s 62 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Rad am Ring Gravel requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on german eifel gravel to build confidence. Expect: german eifel, european gravel, germany.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 62 miles of german eifel gravel in Nürburg, Germany.
